title: R43619
content: Following the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, insurance coverage for terrorism losses changed. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 (TRIA) was passed by Congress to address the disruption in the insurance market. TRIA created a temporary Terrorism Insurance Program to provide government reinsurance for terrorism losses, allowing the private industry time to develop capacity for covering terrorism risk. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA) requires insurers to offer terrorism coverage but does not mandate commercial policyholders to purchase it. The program was extended in 2005 and 2007, with changes focused on reducing government exposure by increasing event size thresholds, insurer deductibles, and post-event recoupment. The 2007 reauthorization expanded coverage to include domestic terrorism acts. The program expired in 2014, with initial thresholds requiring $5 million in insured losses for TRIA coverage. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA) requires $5 million in insured losses for coverage. Once thresholds are met, the government covers 85% of losses with insurers retaining 15%. No premiums are charged, and the Secretary of the Treasury recoups government outlays through a surcharge on insurance policies. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA) requires $5 million in insured losses for coverage, with the government covering 85% of losses. Representative Michael Grimm introduced H.R. 508 to extend the program until the end of 2019, amid uncertainty about the insurance market's reaction to the program's expiration. The bill, H.R. 1945, introduced by Representative Bennie Thompson, aims to extend the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act program until the end of 2024. It also proposes to extend the deadline for mandatory recoupment until September 30, 2024, and includes the Secretary of Homeland Security as the lead authority for certifying acts of terrorism. H.R. 2146, introduced by Representative Michael Capuano, seeks to reauthorize the existing TRIA program for 10 more years until 2024. It also extends the deadline for mandatory recoupment until September 30, 2027, and requires reports on market conditions for terrorism risk insurance in 2017, 2020, and 2023. Senator Charles Schumer's bill, S. 2244, aims to extend the current TRIA program for seven more years until December 31, 2021, while reducing the federal loss sharing amount. S. 2244 aims to extend the TRIA program for seven more years until December 31, 2021, decrease federal loss sharing gradually, increase insurance marketplace retention amount by $2 billion per year, and extend mandatory recoupment dates by seven years. The Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs marked up S. 2244 on June 3, 2014, with amendments including changes to mandatory recoupment provisions, a Treasury study on certification processes, and a GAO study on insurer premiums. Senator Tom Coburn's amendment for timing changes on recoupment was rejected. The bill as amended was favorably reported with a written report filed on June 26, 2024. The Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs marked up S. 2244 on June 3, 2014, with favorable report filed on June 26, 2014. S. 2244 was considered by the full Senate on July 17, 2014, with three amendments adopted. S.Amdt. 3552 added a second title to the bill related to insurance agents and brokers, similar to H.R. 1155 and S. 1926. S.Amdt. 3551 added an advisory committee on risk sharing mechanism, adopted by a vote of 97-0. S.Amdt. 3550 added a section requiring one member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve. The Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs marked up S. 2244 on June 3, 2014, with favorable report filed on June 26, 2014. S. 2244 was considered by the full Senate on July 17, 2014, with amendments adopted, including one requiring a Board of Governors member to have community banking experience. The amended version of S. 2244 was passed by the full Senate on a vote of 93-4. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) released a Statement of Administration Policy (SAP) on July 17, 2014, endorsing the extension of the TRIA program with reforms to reduce taxpayer exposure and increase private sector contributions. The House Committee on Rules reported a rule making in order the House floor consideration of S. 2244 with amendments to extend the program, decrease federal loss sharing, increase program trigger and insurance marketplace retention amounts, extend mandatory recoupment dates, and require recoupment of 140% of federal payments. The substitute amendment for S. 2244 includes provisions to recoup 140% of federal payments, study the certification process, collect additional data on terrorism insurance, and conduct a GAO study on insurer premiums and capital reserve funds for terrorism coverage. It also incorporates the NARAB title for insurance agent licensing and a section on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors makeup. Additionally, it adds a Title III related to the "Business Risk Mitigation and Price Stabilization Act of 2014," which amends derivatives and margin requirements for end users. The House passed H.R. 634 and S. 2244 to extend the TRIA program. H.R. 4871, introduced by Rep. Randy Neugebauer, aims to extend TRIA for five years with changes to reduce government exposure and increase post-event recoupment. Changes include reducing federal share of losses, increasing program trigger amount, and separate treatment for NBCR events. The curr_chunk discusses various proposed changes to the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA), including lower trigger amounts for NBCR terrorist attacks, increased federal loss sharing, mandatory recoupment amounts, opt-out options for small insurers, data collection requirements, and a GAO study on insurer premiums. The House Committee on Financial Services marked up H.R. 4871, including a second title with the National Association of Registered Agents and Brokers Reform Act of 2013. A substitute amendment for a 10-year reauthorization of the current program was rejected. The bill was favorably reported on June 20, 2014, by a vote of 32-27.
